title: Geography Challenge
description: Put your world geography knowledge to the test with questions about capitals, rivers, continents, and more.

questions.question: What is the capital of France?
questions.explanation: Paris has been the capital of France since the 10th century. It is home to over 2 million people and is known as the 'City of Light.'

questions.question: Which is the longest river in the world?
questions.explanation: The Nile River in Africa stretches approximately 4,132 miles, making it the longest river in the world. It flows through 11 countries.

questions.question: How many continents are there on Earth?
questions.explanation: There are seven continents: Africa, Antarctica, Asia, Australia (Oceania), Europe, North America, and South America.

questions.question: Which is the largest continent by area?
questions.explanation: Asia is the largest continent, covering about 17.2 million square miles. It is home to more than 4.5 billion people, over half the world's population.

questions.question: What is the smallest country in the world by area?
questions.explanation: Vatican City is the smallest country in the world at just 0.17 square miles. It is an independent city-state surrounded entirely by Rome, Italy.

questions.question: Which U.S. state is known as the 'Sunshine State'?
questions.explanation: Florida is nicknamed the 'Sunshine State' because of its warm, sunny climate. It became the 27th U.S. state in 1845.

questions.question: What is the capital of Australia?
questions.explanation: Canberra is the capital of Australia, not Sydney or Melbourne. It was purpose-built as the capital in the early 20th century to resolve the rivalry between Sydney and Melbourne.

questions.question: The Amazon River flows through which continent?
questions.explanation: The Amazon flows through South America, primarily through Brazil and Peru. It carries more water than any other river in the world.

questions.question: Which mountain is the tallest in the world, measured from sea level?
questions.explanation: Mount Everest stands at 29,032 feet above sea level, making it the tallest mountain on Earth. It sits on the border between Nepal and Tibet.

questions.question: Which two countries share the longest international border in the world?
questions.explanation: The border between the United States and Canada stretches about 5,525 miles (including the Alaska-Canada border), making it the longest international boundary in the world.

questions.question: What is the driest continent on Earth?
questions.explanation: Antarctica is technically the driest continent, receiving less than 2 inches of precipitation per year on average. Despite being covered in ice, it is classified as a desert.

questions.question: Which European country has the most land area?
questions.explanation: Ukraine is the largest country located entirely within Europe, covering about 233,000 square miles. Russia is larger overall, but most of its territory is in Asia.

questions.question: The Sahara Desert is located on which continent?
questions.explanation: The Sahara Desert covers much of North Africa and is the largest hot desert in the world, spanning about 3.6 million square miles across 11 countries.

questions.question: What is the capital of Japan?
questions.explanation: Tokyo is the capital of Japan and one of the most populous metropolitan areas in the world with over 37 million people in the greater area.

questions.question: Which body of water separates Europe from Africa at its narrowest point?
questions.explanation: The Strait of Gibraltar separates Europe (Spain) from Africa (Morocco) by only about 8.7 miles at its narrowest point, connecting the Atlantic Ocean to the Mediterranean Sea.
